Hi I just made the dough, it's rising right now. I think I'm going to put 
it in the fridge and make it tomorrow. I'm planning to make only donut 
holes. Do u recommend dipping them in the sugar glaze, or do u think it 
would be better if I do the melted butter in cinnamon? Or both? Thank u xx﻿
top_comment.author: Soha Q

comments.text:
+Soha Q love love love these messages. Rock on because they are not the 
easiest recipes. Good for you :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford They turned out AMAZING!!!!! Everyone LOVED them! Thank you 
so so much. I didn't think they would turn out that good because they were 
baked, but I was surprised because everyone thought they were deep fried. 
This recipe made about 70 donut holes. I let them rise a bit longer than 
usual so I guess thats why it made a lot. Also I used cinnamon instead of 
pumpkin pie spice and they were still really really good. Thank u!
comments.author: Soha Q

comments.text:
Hi +Soha Q , For the donut holes dip in butter and then the sugar with 
pumpkin spice or cinnamon. I highly recommend the pumpkin pie spice, there 
is something so moreish about it. Add a pinch of salt into that and you 
will be in heaven. Eat it with chocolate sauce :). The trick is dip them in 
the butter and sugar as soon as they come out of the oven. Let me know how 
they turn out :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

+La Cocina Del Panda heat up the liquid you are going to use for your dough

I love working with fresh yeast.

top_comment.text:
The recipe says 3 1/4 C flour is 460g.  However, the USDA standard for 
sifted all purpose flour is 125g per cup, so it should say 400g.  I made 
this dough using the 400g measurement and it worked out great.  I dumped 
all of the ingredients into my bread maker, starting with the liquids.  
Then I selected the dough cycle and let it do its thing.  90 minutes later, 
it was ready to roll.  Instead of making doughnuts, I formed it into 12 
balls and made some large rolls.  I added some orange glaze and they were 
really good!

I used this same dough recipe last week to make cinnamon rolls with an 
apple glaze.  Yummy!﻿
top_comment.author: Mark Rogers

comments.text: +Gemma Stafford Sounds good.  Thanks!

Gemma.

top_comment.text:
Hi *BOLD BAKERS*! My name is Gemma Stafford and I'm a professional baker 
originally from Ireland. My weekly show *Bigger Bolder Baking* is all about 
showing you how to create over-the-top recipes that are sure to impress. 
This week, I'm making *Homemade Baked Donuts* that I think you'll love more 
than fried without all the fat. I hope you enjoy!

*Gemma's Homemade Donuts: Baked Better than Fried?*
*CLICK LINK below to WATCH*
http://bit.ly/gemmasdonuts﻿

top_comment.text:
After my success with your cinnamon pancakes I decided to give these lovely 
donuts a try, your dough is exactly the same as my monkey bread dough as 
well so I had no trouble making the dough. 
My problem was with the baking, I preheated the oven to 350 and baked for 
13 minutes as instructed but the donuts came out with very browned bottoms 
and the tops were not browned at all like yours, and yes I did brush them 
with butter before baking. 
I wonder what went wrong during baking? 
Your chanel is wonderful and you are an amazing Baker, thanks for all your 
awesome videos! ﻿

can. :)

I will take your advice and try them again soon, even though thy first ones 
I made were a little browned from that bottom everybody still loved them 
and they were gone so fast! 
Thank you so much for the amazing chanel :-)
comments.author: Hafoos483

comments.text:
+Hafoos483 Hi, sorry for my late reply. So what happened was not your 
fault. I will write this in the description. It's the baking tray. The 
baking trays I use are very thick and prevent the bottoms form getting 
brown like that. I made them on a thiner baking sheet and the same happened 
to me. Sorry I never thought to put that in the recipe. I hope they were 
still good to eat :). Thanks so much for watching my videos, I am really 
glad you like them :)

hi Gemma! I dont buy yeast so I was wondering if you HAVE to use yeast?

comments.text:
+Munashe Dumba Unfortunately, you do need yeast for this recipe. It's what

able to buy individual packages at a grocery store for a dollar or so. Can 
you find them where you live?

top_comment.text:
Hey Gemma, You said not to let the yeast come into direct contact with salt 
because it will deactivate it. When you mix the dry ingredients, doesn't 
the salt have a chance of mixing with the yeast?﻿
top_comment.author: mundiman888

comments.text: It does! Thank you!
comments.author: mundiman888

comments.text:
+mundiman888 yeah you are right, it does come in contact with it when you 
mix it but it doesn't all sit directly on the salt in the bowl. It's just 
for when you are adding in your ingredients into the bowl you don't let 
them sit on each other. This rule applies when ever you are using yeast in 
any dough :), make sense?
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Mark Rogers It will work really great as cinnamon rolls for sure. I use a 
serrated knife for carving cinnamon rolls as to not squish the dough like 
the same way you use dental floss :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
I'm a fan of the dough recipe.  It's really good.

I still haven't tried baked donuts, but I made some cinnamon rolls today 
using this dough and they were very good.  Filling: 1/4 C melted butter, 
1/2 C sugar, 2 tsp Saigon cinnamon.  Glaze: Lots of powdered sugar with a 
tiny bit of vanilla and enough apple juice to make it spreadable, but not 
too runny.

Tip of the day: After rolling up the dough, slice it with dental floss.  
Slide the floss under the dough, wrap the ends over the top so it forms a 
loop around the dough, then pull the ends.  It cuts easily without 
squishing the dough flat like a knife tends to do.
comments.author: Mark Rogers

comments.text: +Mark Rogers Thanks Mark, glad you liked them :)

top_comment.text: Hi Gemma!!! Please answer!!!! Can you use cake flour????? Please! Answer! ﻿
top_comment.author: Desmond Chou

comments.text:
+Desmond Chou exactly. Gluten is strong and the gases created by the yeast 
and fermenting get trapped by the gluten and creates the texture. if the 
gluten is not strong it won't be the same .
Glad you like my videos :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text: Love your videos BTW! :D
comments.author: Desmond Chou

comments.text:
Oh thank you I understand I forgot!!!! There's yeast and you need protein 
to create gluten!
comments.author: Desmond Chou

comments.text:
+Desmond Chou hI, Cake flour doesn't have enough gluten, it is too soft to 
mix to a dough. it has to be AP flour :), hope this helps

top_comment.text:
Omg! I love this recipe, and I LOVE donuts but I could never find a good 
enough recipe for baked ones until I saw this recipe. Do you have to use a 
stand mixer, I don't have one could u use a electric mixer or is that out 
of the question?!:) Thanks Gemma for the recipe...😊😝🙌﻿
top_comment.author: Candy Grace

comments.text: Thanks Gemma!:)
comments.author: Candy Grace

comments.text:
+Candy Grace That's great. I personally guarantee you, if you follow my 
recipe and tips you will not go wrong and you will have the best no fried 
donuts, that are not cakey. :)
You can totally do it by hand. But you will need elbow grease. This dough 
is sticky so it won't come together in one ball like bread does. Mix it in 
a bowl. turn it out onto a well floured surface and try kneading by hand. 
Be careful not to add to much flour while kneading or it will change the 
recipe of the donuts. Just knead for as long as you can, maybe a few 
minutes. GOOD LUCK :)!!!!

top_comment.author: Crafty Loops

comments.text:
+Crafty Loops I like to go home at Christmas for the very reasons you said. 
I crave the seasons, especially Fall. It 's in the 20's every day here. 
EVERY DAY!!. Looking forward to going home soon :). Have a good weekend. :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford I didn't know you were from Wexford.  I have family in 
Wicklow, just outside Arklow.  They live about 5 mins drive from Brittas 
Bay.  Its truly stunning down that part of the Country but then I'm lucky 
to have a view of the Mourne Mountains were I am too.  We have had a 
surprising start to Autumn in that this week we've been hitting 
temperatures in the high teens, low 20's.  Yet August here in County Down 
we had some night time temperatures hitting -2!!!  So our Summer was a bit 
of a strange one.  But sure the weather never knows what to be doing in 
Ireland anyway, lol.  It must have taken some adjustment for you being in 
Los Angeles, particularly around Christmas time with it still being so warm 
there.  I have to admit, as much as I hate the cold, I love that we have 
the different seasons at home.  Particularly Autumn, its just so colourful. 
 I've probably made you home sick now Gemma, lol.  Hope you have a great 
weekend.  Lee xx
comments.author: Crafty Loops

comments.text:
+Crafty Loops Aw, that's fantastic. Delighted you liked my video. I love 
hearing from Irish people. Hope your Autumn is going well. I'm from Wexford 
and the weather has been really good the past few weeks. Well so my Dad 
says. I'm in Los Angeles :)

Hey Gemma ;)
Can you show us a perfect recipe for carbonara Pasta please I tried a lot 
of recipes and they weren't creamy and delicious as the ones at the 
restaurant ;)) ﻿
top_comment.author: Christeen Jubran

comments.text: Thanks so much, I really appreciate that +Christeen Jubran :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
Thnx Gemma for helping me I'll try it the way you said I think it's going 
to work that way ;)
You're such a delightful person adore your channel <333
comments.author: Christeen Jubran

comments.text:
+Christeen Jubran Hi Christeen, I am know what you are talking about 
because I have tried and failed this myself. I'm going to let you in on a 
little secret on what goes on in restaurant kitchens, they use cream just 
cream and they reduce it by simmering and concentrate it. It become really 
thick. Then they add A LOT of that thick cream mix to your pasta and that's 
how it tastes like that and why is is very thick. At home, a normal person 
would never use that much cream but that's what they do. 
Traditionally for carbonara the correct technique is to mix cream with an 
egg yolk and that naturally thicken your sauce when you add it to cooked, 
hot pasta. You stir it around to coat the pasta on low heat. You will see 
it thicken, just cook it enough to heat well through and thicken the sauce. 
Add some parmesan which will also thicken your sauce even more and then eat 
:), does this make sense?

comments.text:
+Gemma Stafford Will it still taste like a donut? Also, can you use a 
gluten-free flour?
comments.author: Drama_Llama_5000

comments.text:
+Drama_Llama_5000 Hi, this is a very soft dough so it is quite hard to do 
it by hand. You can try, it will just be a bit messy. If you don't have a 
mixture, then this recipe for cinnamon roll dough is perfect for you 
http://bit.ly/gemmascinnamonrolls . You can shape this dough into donuts :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

top_comment.text:
you are amazing
 Can you make a Video on what you need for begginers baking (like tools)﻿
top_comment.author: Oreen Bm

comments.text:
thank you so much
When I saw your first video it inspired me very much into baking s thank 
you thank you thank you!
comments.author: Oreen Bm

comments.text:
+Oreen Bm Thank you so much! I have a few tips in my Q & A video (
http://bit.ly/gemmasQandA). And I'll be sure to add more to upcoming 
videos. Thank you for watching!
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

top_comment.text:
I don't have a standmixer...can I just use a woodeb spoon to mix the 
ingredients?﻿
top_comment.author: Alina Haque

comments.text: Okay thanks Gemma! Excited to make these donuts (:
comments.author: Alina Haque

comments.text:
+Alina Haque Hi Alina, so this dough is sticky and hard to work with with 
your hands. However I do know one or two people who have kneaded this dough 
by hand and it worked out great. You will need a lot of elbow grease to 
make it without a mixer :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

top_comment.text: hi gemma , how much time do you bake them in the oven ?﻿
top_comment.author: analeelopez8

comments.text: is the dry yeast necessary ? pls let me know , thanks:)
comments.author: analeelopez8

comments.text:
+analeelopez8 13 minutes, be sure to rotate the tray halfway. You can find 
the recipe below the video. Click 'SHOW MORE' and scroll down till you see 
the recipe. Hope that helps :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

top_comment.text:
Where do you get your kitchen equipment? I want to get some new cookie 
cutters or piping bags but I don't want to buy a bad brand. Thanks :) and 
by the way, you channel is GENIUS!!﻿
top_comment.author: Ella Carmen

comments.text: +Gemma Stafford Thank you so much!
comments.author: Ella Carmen

comments.text:
+Ella Carmen Thank you so much Ella, I really appreciate it :). Buy good 
piping bags, bad ones are awful. I shop in William sonoma, sur la table and 
I get cutters and gadgets, spatulas etc in TKMAXX. Tkmaxx has awesome 
kitchen tins, cutters, utensils, spoons so on :).
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

top_comment.text: AWESOME and healthier wow win win!!!﻿

comments.text: +The Lego Minion right?! I love how they turned out. Glad you liked them :)

OMG OMG OMG OMG OMG OMG OMG! The weirdest thing just happened to me just 
now! I was taking a nap and this was playing and I had a nightmare about 
Gemma trying to stuff me up with donuts! Gosh. Lol﻿
top_comment.author: zeibma2011

comments.text: Well I guess, but it sounded more like diabetes heaven :) mmmmmm

comments.text: +zeibma2011 HAHA, someone feeding me donuts sounds like a dream :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

top_comment.text:
can i just melted my butter individually, heat the milk and water mixture a 
bit and wait until its warm enough so i can touch it? because i dont have 
microwave. thankyou!﻿

comments.text: thankyou so much Gemma!

Do a pumpkin pie pleaseeeee :)
Love you﻿
top_comment.author: Gabriela Ramirez

comments.text:
Hi +Gabriela Ramirez I was just looking through my requests and saw you 
aced for pumpkin pie, if you didn't see the video already here it is 
http://bit.ly/1pZKiFB :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text:
+Gabriela Ramirez Absolutely, I will be making Pumpkin pie coming up in

 Thanks so much for watching my videos :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

captions.text: (Music)

Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking
Homemade Donuts

Hi Bold Bakers! This week's recipe has been
the most requested on Bigger Bolder Baking.

What is it? Donuts! More specifically, baked
donuts. My donuts look and taste just like

fried but without all the extra fat. So it's
a win-win! So let's get baking.

So I know what you're thinking, if these are
baked donuts then they're probably those cakey

donuts that you pipe into a mold. No, they're
not. This is a really great yeast dough and

I'm going to keep a big secret about it until
the very end so see if you can figure out what it is.

In stand mixer, we're going to add our flour,
sugar,

salt,
and yeast.

A little tip when adding in yeast. Don't let
it come

in direct contact with the salt or
it will actually deactivate the yeast.

Now mix your ingredients together separately
so everything is well combined.

In a separate jug, we're going to measure
out our milk,

our water,
and butter.

We're going to heat this mix in the microwave
until the butter melts and it's blood temperature.

If you can't feel the liquid around your finger,
it means it's the same temperature as your
blood which means it's blood temperature.

Lastly, add your vanilla extract into your
liquid.
Turn your machine on and add in your liquid.

We're going to mix it on low for two minutes
to actually wake up the yeast and get it activated.

The recipe for this dough can be found below
the video in the description box.

After your two minutes on low,
turn the machine on to medium speed and we're

going to knead for around 6-8 minutes until
it starts to clean the bottom of the bowl.

Our dough is done, it's been on for 8 minutes
and it's good to go.

So we're going to turn it out on a floured
surface.

It's kind of a sticky dough so make sure you
have flour around.

And we're going to scrape the bowl clean
and we're going to pour a little bit of flavorless
oil into the bowl

so it helps the dough to rise and then pop
it back in.

You see when you push on the dough and it
bounces back at you.

That is exactly what you want. It means that
your dough is alive.

Now cover your dough tightly with cling film
so no air gets in

and I like to lay a tea towel over the top
to keep it warm.

And just so you know, you can make this dough
the day before and then bake it the next day.

Now we're one step closer to making our homemade
donuts.

It's been two hours, our dough is looking
fantastic so we're going to turn it out onto
a floured surface.

Roll your dough out to around 1/2 an inch
thick. We want our donuts to be nice and big.
This is Bigger Bolder Baking after all.

To cut your doughnuts, you do not need a special
donut cutter. I just use a regular cutter

and to cut out the donut hole
I just use the bottom of a piping tip.
Then just tap out your donut hole.

And then straight onto a baking tray and
give them a little bit of space so they can
rise and grow.

My first job in the United States was actually
as a bread baker. And I used to have to get

up and go to work at 3am in the freezing cold
and snow.
But I loved it.

So because this is Bigger Bolder Baking, we're
going to make a few different varieties of
homemade donuts.

If you want to make stuffed donuts,
just cut another round and don't cut out a donut hole

With the leftover dough
gently rework it and cut out more donuts.

Once you've cut out your donuts, we need to
proof them again

a little bit longer for around another 30
minutes
and then they're ready for the oven.

Our donuts are proofed and they actually only
took only 20 minutes

You can tell when they're done when they're
nice and rounded out.

You see how you can't see the lines of the
cutter anymore.

Before they go in the oven, we're just going
to brush the tops with melted butter and this
gives them a really nice color.

Now one thing I Iike to do when working with
yeast dough is to sprinkle the tray with water

so then when the water evaporates it creates
steam and it

helps all of the yeast to rise and also I
think it gives your donuts a nice soft top.

Our donuts are ready for the oven.
I can't wait for them to be baked.

While our donuts are in the oven, we're going
to get cracking on the glaze because we want

to dip them straight away when they come out
of the oven.

In a large bowl,
add in your icing sugar,

Vanilla extract,
and a little bit of water.

And then just whisk together.
Add enough water to get a thin icing.

This glaze is really easy
and it's very reminiscent of a Krispy Kreme flavor if you know what I mean.

Our donuts are finished baking. You would
not believe what my kitchen smells like right now.
Look at these beautiful donuts!

Why would you eat fried if you could just
bake them off and they're going to be just
as good. Oh man, they smell so good. Ok, I have to stop touching them. We're going to
glaze them and we're going to get eatin'.

Once your donuts come out of the oven, the
best thing to do is glaze them straight away

because all that warm dough kind of soaks
up the glaze and that's exactly what you want.
Can you believe these are baked donuts?

What I like to do with these donuts is to
actually double dip them in the glaze.

So I do one layer, let it set
then I put them back in again for another layer.
It makes them really good and keeps them nice and soft.

If you needed any convincing that these are
donuts
then just look at this!
So now it's time to get really BIG & BOLD.

Dip your donut holes in butter while they're
still warm

and then toss them in sugar and pumpkin pie
spice.
I love the sweet and salty flavors together.

I like to serve these donut holes around the
holidays for easy entertaining with chocolate sauce.

Oh, these are so good.
Check these out. By tasting this you'd never know it was a baked donut.

So do you remember these donuts that we made
for stuffing? We are going to fill them with Nutella.

Just make an incision in the bottom,
fill your piping bag with Nutella,

and then squeeze.
You will actually see it getting bigger.
And then add a swirl to the top.

Now you have a BIG & BOLD box of homemade
donuts.

Remember that secret I mentioned earlier,
well my donut dough is also my Monkey Bread
dough. It works really well for both.

I really hope you guys try out my homemade
baked donuts. You will not be disappointed.

Don't forget to subscribe to my channel and
I'll see you back here again next Thursday
for more Bigger Bolder Baking.

title: Homemade Donuts: Baked Better than Fried? - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking Ep 32
